cards.name: Decree of Justice
cards.text:
Create X 4/4 white Angel creature tokens with flying.
Cycling {2}{W} ({2}{W}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Decree of Justice, you may pay {X}. If you do, create X 1/1 white Soldier creature tokens.

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

When you cycle this card, first the cycling ability goes on the stack, then the triggered ability goes on the stack on top of it. The triggered ability will resolve before you draw a card from the cycling ability.

The cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. If the triggered ability doesn’t resolve (due to being countered with Stifle, for example, or if all its targets have become illegal), the cycling ability will still resolve and you’ll draw a card.
A mana cost of {X}{X} means that you pay twice X. If you want X to be 3, you pay {8}{W}{W} to cast Decree of Justice.

cards.name: Vengeful Dreams
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, discard X cards.
Exile X target attacking creatures.
cards.flavorText: Teroh dreams of his enemies' doom.

cards.name: Aquamoeba
cards.text: Discard a card: Switch Aquamoeba's power and toughness until end of turn.
cards.flavorText: Some tides need no moon.

rulings.text: Effects that switch a creature’s power and toughness apply after all other effects, regardless of when those effects began to apply. For instance, if you target a 1/2 creature then give it +2/+0 later in the turn, it’s a 2/3 creature, not a 4/1 creature.

Because damage remains marked on a creature until the damage is removed as the turn ends, nonlethal damage dealt to a creature may become lethal if you switch its power and toughness during that turn.
Switching a creature’s power and toughness twice (or any even number of times) effectively returns the creature to the power and toughness it had before any switches.

cards.name: Wing Shards
cards.text:
Target player sacrifices an attacking creature.
Storm (When you cast this spell, copy it for each spell cast before it this turn. You may choose new targets for the copies.)

rulings.text: If you cast Wing Shards after combat damage has been dealt, only creatures that survived combat can be sacrificed.

An “attacking creature” is one that has been declared as an attacker or put onto the battlefield attacking during a turn’s combat. Unless that creature leaves combat, it continues to be an attacking creature through the end of combat step, even if the player it was attacking has left the game or the planeswalker it was attacking has left combat.
Wing Shards doesn’t target the creature to be sacrificed. The target player chooses the creature as it resolves.
The copies storm creates are created on the stack, so they’re not cast. Abilities that trigger when a player casts a spell (such as storm) won’t trigger.
Storm counts spells cast before the spell with storm was cast. Spells cast after the spell with storm was cast but before the storm ability resolves aren’t counted.
The storm ability and the copies it creates all resolve before the spell with storm. They resolve even if the spell with storm is countered.

cards.name: Exalted Angel
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever Exalted Angel deals damage, you gain that much life.
Morph {2}{W}{W} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)

rulings.text: You only gain the life when the triggered ability resolves. If you are reduced to zero life before the ability resolves, you will lose before gaining the life.

cards.name: Circular Logic
cards.text:
Counter target spell unless its controller pays {1} for each card in your graveyard.
Madness {U} (If you discard this card, discard it into exile. When you do, cast it for its madness cost or put it into your graveyard.)

rulings.text: Circular Logic is still on the stack while you count the number of cards in your graveyard. It doesn’t count itself.

rulings.text: Circular Logic is still on the stack while you count the number of cards in your graveyard. It doesn’t count itself.

cards.text:

cards.name: Compulsion
cards.text:
{1}{U}, Discard a card: Draw a card.
{1}{U}, Sacrifice Compulsion: Draw a card.

cards.name: Deep Analysis
cards.text:
Target player draws two cards.
Flashback—{1}{U}, Pay 3 life. (You may cast this card from your graveyard for its flashback cost. Then exile it.)
cards.flavorText: "The specimen seems to be broken."

rulings.text: “Flashback [cost]” means “You may cast this card from your graveyard by paying [cost] rather than paying its mana cost” and “If the flashback cost was paid, exile this card instead of putting it anywhere else any time it would leave the stack.”

You must still follow any timing restrictions and permissions, including those based on the card's type. For instance, you can cast a sorcery using flashback only when you could normally cast a sorcery.

To determine the total cost of a spell, start with the mana cost or alternative cost (such as a flashback cost) you're paying, add any cost increases, then apply any cost reductions. The mana value of the spell is determined only by its mana cost, no matter what the total cost to cast the spell was.
A spell cast using flashback will always be exiled afterward, whether it resolves, is countered, or leaves the stack in some other way.
You can cast a spell using flashback even if it was somehow put into your graveyard without having been cast.
If a card with flashback is put into your graveyard during your turn, you can cast it if it's legal to do so before any other player can take any actions.

cards.name: Cunning Wish
cards.text: You may reveal an instant card you own from outside the game and put it into your hand. Exile Cunning Wish.
cards.flavorText: He wished for knowledge, but not for the will to apply it.

rulings.text: Can’t acquire the Ante cards. They are considered still “in the game” as are cards in the library and the graveyard.
The choice is optional.
If you fail to find something, you still exile this.
Can’t acquire cards that are phased out.
You can’t acquire exiled cards because those cards are still in one of the game’s zones.
In a sanctioned event, a card that’s “outside the game” is one that’s in your sideboard. In an unsanctioned event, you may choose any card from your collection.

cards.name: Envelop
cards.text: Counter target sorcery spell.
cards.flavorText:
"What you made will be unmade. What you learned will be unlearned. And when you're done, you will be undone."
—Ambassador Laquatus

cards.name: Ray of Distortion
cards.text:
Destroy target artifact or enchantment.
Flashback {4}{W}{W} (You may cast this card from your graveyard for its flashback cost. Then exile it.)

cards.name: Stupefying Touch
cards.text:
Enchant creature
When Stupefying Touch enters the battlefield, draw a card.
Enchanted creature's activated abilities can't be activated.
cards.flavorText: Just because your eyes are open doesn't mean you're awake.

rulings.text: Activated abilities contain a colon. They’re generally written “[Cost]: [Effect].” Some keywords are activated abilities and will have colons in their reminder text.
Unlike many similar abilities, Stupefying Touch’s last ability stops mana abilities from being activated.

cards.name: Quiet Speculation
cards.text: Search target player's library for up to three cards with flashback and put them into that player's graveyard. Then the player shuffles.
cards.flavorText:
"The best foresight is hindsight."
—Empress Llawan

cards.name: Renewed Faith
cards.text:
You gain 6 life.
Cycling {1}{W} ({1}{W}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Renewed Faith, you may gain 2 life.

rulings.text: When you cycle this card, first the cycling ability goes on the stack, then the triggered ability goes on the stack on top of it. The triggered ability will resolve before you draw a card from the cycling ability.

The cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. If the triggered ability doesn't resolve (due to being countered with Stifle, for example, or if all its targets have become illegal), the cycling ability will still resolve and you'll draw a card.

Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.
Some cards with cycling have an ability that triggers when you cycle them. These triggered abilities resolve before you draw from the cycling ability.
Triggered abilities from cycling a card and the cycling ability itself aren't spells. Effects that interact with spells (such as that of Cancel) won't affect them.

You can cycle a card even if it has a triggered ability from cycling that won't have a legal target. This is because the cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. This also means that if either ability doesn't resolve (due to being countered with Disallow, for example, or if the triggered ability's targets have become illegal), the other ability will still resolve.

There are many important moments in the story, but the most crucial—called “story spotlights”—are shown on cards. These cards have the Planeswalker symbol in their text box; this symbol has no effect on gameplay. You can read more about these events in the official Magic fiction at http://www.mtgstory.com.

cards.name: Arcanis the Omnipotent
cards.text:
{T}: Draw three cards.
{2}{U}{U}: Return Arcanis the Omnipotent to its owner's hand.
cards.flavorText: He has journeyed where none have been before. Now he returns to ensure that none follow.

rulings.text: Arcanis's last ability can only be activated while it's on the battlefield.

cards.name: Guiltfeeder
cards.text:
Fear (This creature can't be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or black creatures.)
Whenever Guiltfeeder attacks and isn't blocked, defending player loses 1 life for each card in their graveyard.

rulings.text: An ability that triggers when something “attacks and isn’t blocked” triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.name: Careful Study
cards.text: Draw two cards, then discard two cards.
cards.flavorText: Books are like crops—they must be thinned for best yield.

cards.name: Stitch Together
cards.text:
Return target creature card from your graveyard to your hand.
Threshold — Return that card from your graveyard to the battlefield instead if seven or more cards are in your graveyard.

rulings.text: Checks the number of cards in your graveyard when it starts resolving. You may drop below seven cards during resolution, but that won’t stop it from resolving.

cards.name: Stitch Together

cards.text:
Haste
As long as Anger is in your graveyard and you control a Mountain, creatures you control have haste.
cards.flavorText:
"For its time as a mortal, Anger chose a shell of boiling rock."
—*Scroll of Beginnings*

rulings.text: The timestamp for the “in your graveyard” ability is set at the time that this card goes to your graveyard, regardless of whether you control a Mountain at that time.

cards.name: Burning Wish
cards.text: You may reveal a sorcery card you own from outside the game and put it into your hand. Exile Burning Wish.
cards.flavorText: She wished for a weapon, but not for the skill to wield it.

In a sanctioned event, a card that’s “outside the game” is one that’s in your sideboard. In an unsanctioned event, you may choose any card from your collection.

cards.name: Sickening Dreams
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, discard X cards.
Sickening Dreams deals X damage to each creature and each player.
cards.flavorText: The Patriarch dreams of vile plague.

cards.name: Flaring Pain
cards.text:
Damage can't be prevented this turn.
Flashback {R} (You may cast this card from your graveyard for its flashback cost. Then exile it.)
cards.flavorText:
"I don't rub salt in wounds. I use sulfur."
—Matoc, lavamancer

rulings.text: Spells and abilities that replace or redirect damage are not affected by this card.
The “damage can’t be prevented” statement overrides all forms of preventing damage. Damage prevention spells and abilities can still be cast and activated, they just don’t do anything.

cards.name: Mana Leak
cards.text: Counter target spell unless its controller pays {3}.
cards.flavorText: The fatal flaw in every plan is the assumption that you know more than your enemy.

cards.text: Counter target spell unless its controller pays {3}.

cards.name: Gempalm Incinerator
cards.text:
Cycling {1}{R} ({1}{R}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
When you cycle Gempalm Incinerator, you may have it deal X damage to target creature, where X is the number of Goblins on the battlefield.

rulings.text: The target of the ability can’t be a creature with Protection from Creatures, with Protection from Goblins, or with Protection from Red.

Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

When you cycle this card, first the cycling ability goes on the stack, then the triggered ability goes on the stack on top of it. The triggered ability will resolve before you draw a card from the cycling ability.

The cycling ability and the triggered ability are separate. If the triggered ability doesn’t resolve (due to being countered with Stifle, for example, or if all its targets have become illegal), the cycling ability will still resolve and you’ll draw a card.
You can cycle this card even if there are no targets for the triggered ability. That’s because the cycling ability itself has no targets.

cards.name: Goblin Warchief
cards.text:
Goblin spells you cast cost {1} less to cast.
Goblins you control have haste.
cards.flavorText: They poured from the Skirk Ridge like lava, burning and devouring everything in their path.

rulings.text: Goblin Warchief’s effect reduces only generic mana in the cost of Goblin spells you cast. For example, it doesn’t reduce the cost of Skirk Prospector below {R}.

cards.name: Goblin Grappler
cards.text: Provoke (Whenever this creature attacks, you may have target creature defending player controls untap and block it if able.)
cards.flavorText: Daru soldiers learned it's better to have a clean death from a sharp blade than to tangle with a goblin's rusted chains.

cards.name: Siege-Gang Commander
cards.text:
When Siege-Gang Commander enters the battlefield, create three 1/1 red Goblin creature tokens.
{1}{R}, Sacrifice a Goblin: Siege-Gang Commander deals 2 damage to any target.

rulings.text: You can sacrifice any Goblin you control to activate Siege-Gang Commander’s activated ability, not just the ones its triggered ability puts onto the battlefield. You can even sacrifice Siege-Gang Commander itself.

cards.name: Sulfuric Vortex
cards.text:
At the beginning of each player's upkeep, Sulfuric Vortex deals 2 damage to that player.
If a player would gain life, that player gains no life instead.

cards.name: Unsummon
cards.text: Return target creature to its owner's hand.

cards.text: Return target creature to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Buried Alive
cards.text: Search your library for up to three creature cards, put them into your graveyard, then shuffle.
cards.flavorText: The scrape of shovels and the tumble of cold dirt soon muffled their pleas.

rulings.text: You can look in your library and then choose to find any number from zero to three creatures after you look at it.

Trample
Madness {2}{G} (If you discard this card, discard it into exile. When you do, cast it for its madness cost or put it into your graveyard.)

cards.name: Basking Rootwalla
cards.text:
{1}{G}: Basking Rootwalla gets +2/+2 until end of turn. Activate only once each turn.
Madness {0} (If you discard this card, discard it into exile. When you do, cast it for its madness cost or put it into your graveyard.)

rulings.text: If this card’s ability is activated by one player, then another player takes control of it on the same turn, the second player can’t activate its ability that turn.

cards.name: Hunting Pack
cards.text:
Create a 4/4 green Beast creature token.
Storm (When you cast this spell, copy it for each spell cast before it this turn.)

rulings.text: The copies are put directly onto the stack. They aren't cast and won't be counted by other spells with storm cast later in the turn.
Spells cast from zones other than a player's hand and spells that were countered are counted by the storm ability.
A copy of a spell can be countered like any other spell, but it must be countered individually. Countering a spell with storm won't affect the copies.
The triggered ability that creates the copies can itself be countered by anything that can counter a triggered ability. If it is countered, no copies will be put onto the stack.

cards.name: Krosan Reclamation
cards.text:
Target player shuffles up to two target cards from their graveyard into their library.

cards.text:

cards.name: Dark Banishing
cards.text: Destroy target nonblack creature. It can't be regenerated.
cards.flavorText:
"Ha, banishment? Be merciful, say 'death,' For exile hath more terror in his look, Much more than death."
—William Shakespeare, *Romeo and Juliet*

cards.name: Phantom Centaur
cards.text:
Protection from black
Phantom Centaur enters the battlefield with three +1/+1 counters on it.
If damage would be dealt to Phantom Centaur, prevent that damage. Remove a +1/+1 counter from Phantom Centaur.

rulings.text: If this card is going to take damage from a black source, you can choose to apply Protection from Black’s damage prevention ability prior to applying this card’s built-in ability. This means you don’t have to remove a counter.
If this card takes damage from multiple sources at once (for example if it is blocked by multiple creatures in combat), it only loses one counter.
If unpreventable damage is applied to this card, you still remove a counter even though the prevention fails.
Remove one counter each time it would be damaged. If it was going to take more than one point of damage, you prevent all the damage and still only remove one counter.
The damage prevention ability works even if it has no counters, as long as some effect keeps its toughness above zero.

cards.name: Decompose
cards.text: Exile up to three target cards from a single graveyard.
cards.flavorText:
"Sheesh! How am I supposed to make a decent living around here?"
—Cabal grave robber

cards.name: Entomb
cards.text: Search your library for a card, put that card into your graveyard, then shuffle.
cards.flavorText: A grave is the safest place to store ill-gotten treasures.

cards.name: Nantuko Vigilante
cards.text:
Morph {1}{G} (You may cast this card face down as a 2/2 creature for {3}. Turn it face up any time for its morph cost.)
When Nantuko Vigilante is turned face up, destroy target artifact or enchantment.

rulings.text: The trigger occurs when you use the Morph ability to turn the card face up, or when an effect turns it face up. It will not trigger on being revealed or on leaving the battlefield.

cards.name: Anurid Brushhopper
cards.text: Discard two cards: Exile Anurid Brushhopper. Return it to the battlefield under its owner's control at the beginning of the next end step.
cards.flavorText: It's so tough it can frighten itself into hiding.

cards.name: Mirari's Wake
cards.text:
Creatures you control get +1/+1.
Whenever you tap a land for mana, add one mana of any type that land produced.
cards.flavorText: The land drank power from the Mirari as though it had thirsted forever.

rulings.text: Because damage remains marked on a creature until the cleanup step or an effect removes that damage, nonlethal damage dealt to creatures you control may become lethal if Mirari's Wake leaves the battlefield.
The types of mana are white, blue, black, red, green, and colorless.
If tapping a land produces more than one type of mana, you choose one type that was produced and add one mana of that type.
If the mana produced by the land has any additional restrictions or riders, those restrictions or riders don't apply to the mana added by Mirari's Wake. You just get one mana of the appropriate type.

cards.name: Doomed Necromancer
cards.text: {B}, {T}, Sacrifice Doomed Necromancer: Return target creature card from your graveyard to the battlefield.
cards.flavorText:
"His sacrifice shall not be forgotten. Now toss his body over there with the others."
—Phage the Untouchable

rulings.text: Because targets are chosen before costs are paid, Doomed Necromancer can't be the target of its own ability.

cards.name: Krosan Verge
cards.text:
Krosan Verge enters the battlefield tapped.
{T}: Add {C}.
{2}, {T}, Sacrifice Krosan Verge: Search your library for a Forest card and a Plains card, put them onto the battlefield tapped, then shuffle.

cards.name: Haunting Echoes
cards.text: Exile all cards from target player's graveyard other than basic land cards. For each card exiled this way, search that player's library for all cards with the same name as that card and exile them. Then that player shuffles.

rulings.text: While you’re searching the player’s library, you don’t have to find all the cards with the same name as an exiled card if you don’t want to. You can leave any number of them in that player’s library.

cards.name: Innocent Blood
cards.text: Each player sacrifices a creature.
cards.flavorText: Zombies mourn for the living and celebrate those who will soon be given the gift of death.

rulings.text: You can cast Innocent Blood even if some (or all) players control no creatures. Those players are simply unaffected.

cards.name: Last Rites
cards.text: Discard any number of cards. Target player reveals their hand, then you choose a nonland card from it for each card discarded this way. That player discards those cards.

cards.name: Patriarch's Bidding
cards.text: Each player chooses a creature type. Each player returns all creature cards of a type chosen this way from their graveyard to the battlefield.
cards.flavorText:
"Family plots are so convenient."
—Cabal Patriarch

rulings.text: The player whose turn it is chooses a creature type first, followed by each other player in turn order. Then, all creature cards that have one or more of the chosen types are returned to the battlefield at the same time.
Any player may choose a creature type that's already been chosen. Doing so won't affect which creature cards are returned to the battlefield.
Each player may choose any creature type, even if they don't have any creature cards of that type in their graveyard.
You must choose a creature type, such as Elf or Shaman. You can't choose other card types such as artifact or supertypes such as legendary.

cards.name: Patriarch's Bidding

cards.name: Soul Feast
cards.text: Target player loses 4 life and you gain 4 life.
cards.flavorText: You are who you eat.

cards.name: Smother
cards.text: Destroy target creature with mana value 3 or less. It can't be regenerated.
cards.flavorText:
"I can't hear them scream, but at least I don't have to listen to them beg."
—Phage the Untouchable

rulings.text: A creature's mana value is determined solely by the mana symbols printed in its upper right corner (unless that creature is copying something else; see below). If its mana cost includes {X}, X is considered to be 0. If it has no mana symbols in its upper right corner (because it's an animated land, for example), its mana value is 0. Ignore any alternative costs or additional costs (such as kicker) paid when the creature was cast.
A token has a mana value of 0, unless it is copying something else.
If a creature is copying something else, its mana value is the mana value of whatever it's copying.

rulings.text: The ability to return to your hand can only be activated while this card is in your graveyard.

Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

cards.flavorText: It teaches *you* to play dead.

cards.name: Symbiotic Wurm
cards.text: When Symbiotic Wurm dies, create seven 1/1 green Insect creature tokens.
cards.flavorText: The insects keep the wurm's hide free from parasites. In return, the wurm doesn't eat the insects.

cards.name: Mirari
cards.text: Whenever you cast an instant or sorcery spell, you may pay {3}. If you do, copy that spell. You may choose new targets for the copy.
cards.flavorText:
"It offers you what you want, not what you need."
—Braids, dementia summoner

rulings.text: Everything about the original spell is copied, including any decisions made on announcement, such as whether it was kicked or its Buyback cost was paid. Effects on the spell, such as Sleight of Mind or Flashback, are not copied.
If the copied spell requires a target and there are no legal targets, then the copy has the same target (which should be illegal) as the original.
If the spell is countered before the triggered ability resolves, then the ability will make a copy of how the spell looked right before it was countered.
It triggers once per spell, so you can’t get multiple copies of a spell using this card. And since this card is legendary, you can’t control more than one.
The copy is not “cast” so it will not trigger anything that triggers on a spell being cast.
You choose whether or not to pay when the triggered ability resolves.

You are not required to choose new targets. If you do choose, then the targets must be legal. If you don’t change them, the spell is placed on the stack whether or not the targets are legal. The legality of the targets is always checked on resolution of the spell, so the spell may be countered at that time if all of its targets are illegal.

cards.name: Barren Moor
cards.text:
Barren Moor enters the battlefield tapped.
{T}: Add {B}.
Cycling {B} ({B}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)

rulings.text: Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

cards.text: {T}, Pay 1 life, Sacrifice Bloodstained Mire: Search your library for a Swamp or Mountain card, put it onto the battlefield, then shuffle.

cards.name: Centaur Garden
cards.text:
{T}: Add {G}. Centaur Garden deals 1 damage to you.
Threshold — {G}, {T}, Sacrifice Centaur Garden: Target creature gets +3/+3 until end of turn. Activate only if seven or more cards are in your graveyard.

cards.name: Flooded Strand
cards.text: {T}, Pay 1 life, Sacrifice Flooded Strand: Search your library for a Plains or Island card, put it onto the battlefield, then shuffle.

cards.name: City of Brass
cards.text:
Whenever City of Brass becomes tapped, it deals 1 damage to you.
{T}: Add one mana of any color.

rulings.text: The first ability triggers no matter how the land becomes tapped.

If you tap City of Brass while you are casting a spell or activating an ability, its ability will trigger and wait. When you finish casting that spell or activating that ability, City of Brass’s triggered ability is put on the stack on top of it. City of Brass’s ability will resolve first.

On the other hand, you can tap City of Brass, put its triggered ability on the stack, and then respond to that ability by casting an instant or activating an ability using that mana. In that case, the instant spell or activated ability will resolve first.

cards.flavorText: The carnage of conflicts long past still stains the Otarian soil.

tokens.name: Dave Humpherys Bio
tokens.text: The Top 8 is familiar territory for professional Magic player Dave Humpherys. With over $130,000 in career winnings and a Pro Tour championship on his resume, "The Hump" advanced to the Worlds semifinals for the second year in a row where he lost to eventual champion Daniel Zink. The blue-green madness deck he played has been a Standard mainstay for more than a year. It revolves around Torment madness cards like Basking Rootwalla and Circular Logic, together with discard-enablers like Aquamoeba and Wild Mongrel. Humpherys, who recently earned his Ph.D. from MIT, credits this version of the deck to Norway's Sigurd Eskeland.

tokens.name: Daniel Zink Bio
tokens.text: Daniel Zink, a student from Bochum, Germany, players the control deck that defined this year's World Championships. The white-blue-green "Wake" deck is named after the powerful enchantment that's the heart of the deck. Once Mirari's Wake is in play, the deck produces more mana, draws more cards, counters more spells, and makes more Soldiers than opponents can possibly handle. Zink had help from fellow German and 2002-2003 Player of the Year Kai Budde in adapting the "Wake" deck to the post—Eigth Edition environment.

tokens.name: Wolfgang Eder Bio
tokens.text: Wolfgang Eder introduced this black-red "Goblin Bidding" deck to the world at this year's European Championships. The twenty-two-year-old student from Weinheim, Germany, says the inspiration for the deck came from trying to give the typical Goblin tribe something to do in the midgame. He achieved this by adding black to the deck for Patriarch's Bidding, which brings every Goblin in the graveyard back to play. And with cards like Goblin Warchief and Siege-Gang Commander, those Goblins have haste and bring friends with them! A resolved Patriarch's Bidding is usually game over.

tokens.name: Peer Kröger Bio
tokens.text: Hometown hero Peer Kröger played his own version of the classic "Reanimator" deck to an impressive record during this year's World Championships. The twenty-eight-year-old communications and computer science student nicknamed his deck "Herbert Wise" after the famous H. P. Lovecraft work "Herbert Wise—Reanimator." Winning with this deck is a two-step process: Step 1. Use Entomb or Buried Alive to quickly get daunting creatures into the graveyard. Step 2. Bring the creature back to life with Zombify or Doomed Necromancer. The mostly black deck also uses Burning Wish to find just the right answers to deal with opponents' plans.
